text: Protein kinase C and calcineurin synergize to activate IkappaB kinase and NF-kappaB in T lymphocytes .
The nuclear factor of kappaB ( NF-kappaB ) is a ubiquitous transcription factor that is key in the regulation of the immune response and inflammation .

T cell receptor ( TCR ) cross-linking is in part required for activation of NF-kappaB , which is dependent on the phosphorylation and degradation of <extra_id_0> IkappaBalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

text: By using Jurkat and primary human T lymphocytes , we demonstrate that the simultaneous activation of two second messengers of the TCR - initiated signal transduction , protein kinase C ( PKC ) and calcineurin , results in the synergistic activation of the IkappaBalpha kinase ( IKK ) complex but not of another putative <extra_id_0> IkappaBalpha kinase <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> p90(rsk) <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

We also demonstrate that the IKK complex , but not <extra_id_0> p90(rsk) <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , is responsible for the in vivo phosphorylation of <extra_id_0> IkappaBalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mediated by the co - activation of PKC and calcineurin .

text: Each second messenger is necessary , as inhibition of either one reverses the activation of the IKK complex and <extra_id_0> IkappaBalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> phosphorylation in vivo .

text: Overexpression of dominant negative forms of <extra_id_0> IKKalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> -beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> demonstrates that only <extra_id_0> IKKbeta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is the target for PKC and calcineurin .
These results indicate that within the TCR / CD3 signal transduction pathway both PKC and calcineurin are required for the effective activation of the IKK complex and NF-kappaB in T lymphocytes .
